name: Articulation Evaluation Protocol
description: Evaluation protocol overview and component selection
html_template:
Articulation Evaluation Protocol

An articulation evaluation was conducted to assess 's ability to produce speech sounds clearly and appropriately for their age. The purpose of the evaluation is to identify any speech sound errors that may affect ability to communicate effectively. Errors in articulation can significantly affect ability to be understood, academic performance, and social interactions. By understanding specific speech patterns, we can create a tailored intervention plan to improve overall communication skills.

The evaluation included the following components:

This thorough process allows us to gain a clear picture of your child's speech strengths and challenges and to make informed recommendations for therapy. All measures were performed in: . Results of all formal and informal assessments appear to be reliable.

name: Oral Mechanism Evaluation
description: Assessment of oral speech mechanism structure and function
html_template:
Oral Mechanism Evaluation

Informal assessment of the oral speech mechanism was performed through observation to assess the adequacy of the structures and functions of the oral-motor mechanism. This includes evaluating the symmetry, strength, coordination, and range of motion of the oral structures, as well as breath support and motor control.

Structure Assessment

Face

Mandible and Maxilla

Teeth and Dental Occlusion

Palatal Arch

Lips

Function Assessment

Jaw Function

Velopharyngeal Closure

Phonation and Breath Support

Oral Reflexes

Motor Speech Coordination

name: Speech Sound Assessment
description: Comprehensive phoneme assessment with detailed error analysis
html_template:
Speech Sound Assessment

Speech Sound Assessment: The ability to produce speech sounds was assessed throughout the course of the evaluation in order to measure articulation of sounds and determine types of misarticulation. The Clinical Assessment of Articulation and Phonology - 2nd Edition (CAAP-2) was administered. Additionally, spontaneous speech was elicited both in words and connected speech. Data was collected and analyzed using the Age of Customary Consonant Production chart as recommended by The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA). The acquisition of speech sounds is a developmental process and children often demonstrate "typical" errors and phonological patterns during this acquisition period. Developmentally appropriate error patterns were taken into consideration during assessment of speech sounds in order to differentiate typical errors from those that are not.

name: Language Sample Analysis
description: Analysis of spontaneous language including structure, content, and social use
html_template:
Language Sample Analysis

A language sample was obtained to evaluate spontaneous speech and obtain more information about language skills in a less structured environment. The language sample was collected informally through play and observed for semantic, syntactic, morphological and pragmatic language abilities.

Language Content

Social Language Use

name: Standardized Assessment
description: Formal standardized test results with scoring interpretation
html_template:
Standardized Assessment

Formal standardized assessments were administered to evaluate speech and language skills. Results are interpreted based on standard scores with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of ±15.

Standard Score Range Interpretation
Above 115 Above Average
85-115 Average/Within Normal Limits
78-84 Marginal/Below Average/Mild
71-77 Low Range/Moderate
70-50 Very Low Range/Severe
Below 50 Profound

Preschool Language Scale – Fifth Edition (PLS-5)

The PLS-5 is designed to assess receptive and expressive language skills in children from birth through 7 years, 11 months of age.

Subtest Standard Score Confidence Interval Percentile Rank Age Equivalent Severity
Auditory Comprehension
Expressive Communication
Total Language Score

Relative Strengths

Clinical Impressions
